body:
Confirmed that this will create invalid SQL at least on MySQL.
1. We could add a check to see if the rows array is empty, but then do we throw an exception or not? --> Not doing the query still means my request has succeeded (I've successfully inserted an empty set)
2. While we are at it we might also want to check each row for the proper number of fields.
@samdark Feel free to assign this to me after answering my questions ^^

1. Inserting nothing when nothing was provided is a success. Should not throw exception.
2. Won't DB do it by itself?
Yes database will check it but if the batch is big it will be faster to check it yourselves; basically we save the round-trip to the db.
But it will slow down every proper query.

We loop over the array anyway, it'll be O(2n) which it the same; I'll
benchmark it.
On Jun 7, 2016 8:49 PM, "Robert Korulczyk" notifications@github.com wrote:

> But it will slow down every proper query.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/issues/11693#issuecomment-224377275, or mute
> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe/AAhYzd8qNqRKZ2TaHYnA1dPWy7k5Adspks5qJb07gaJpZM4IuJBi
> .
But what is the point of duplicate this validation to increase performance of **incorrect** code?

Better error handling; isn't it essentially the same as the unique
validator?

What do you suggest?
On Jun 7, 2016 10:27 PM, "Robert Korulczyk" notifications@github.com
wrote:

> But what is the point of duplicate this validation to increase performance
> of _incorrect_ code?
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/issues/11693#issuecomment-224403277, or mute
> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe/AAhYzbux5J2Gz2HGYxrCawPNTsIU_Pa5ks5qJdQqgaJpZM4IuJBi
> .
I suggest ignoring this case. It's not likely to happen when system gone live.

> What do you suggest?

I suggest ignore it. Unique validator is only validator, not internal and mandatory additional validation - you are free to not use unique validator if you know what you're doing. 
Besides, if data for `batchInsert()` came from user input, it should be already validated by validation rules. You suggest validate this three times - first by validators, second by additional check in `batchInsert()` and the third time by DBMS.

I have the same issue on Postgres, using batchInsert in migrations.
Calling batchInsert with an empty array generates invalid SQL like

`INSERT INTO table (col1, col2) VALUES;`

I was thinking about fixing it with just returning an empty string if array is empty, but I'm not so deep into Yii to know if that would have any side effect...

issue.title: Handle batchInsert() with no data to insert.

repository.name: yii2
repository.description: Yii 2: The Fast, Secure and Professional PHP Framework

fix #11693

issue.title: batchInsert with empty rows ( yield )

repository.name: yii2
repository.description: Yii 2: The Fast, Secure and Professional PHP Framework

issue.body:
### What steps will reproduce the problem?
```php
function getRows() {
    if (false) {
        yield [];
    }
}

\Yii::$app->db->createCommand()
    ->batchInsert('{{customer}}', ['email', 'name', 'address'], getRows())
    ->execute();
```

### What is the expected result?
Skip execution of empty sql query
https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/issues/11693

### What do you get instead?
```
PDOException: SQLSTATE[42601]: Syntax error: 7 ERROR:  syntax error at end of input
LINE 1: INSERT INTO "customer" ("email", "name", "address") VALUES 
                                                                   ^
```

### Additional info

| Q                | A
| ---------------- | ---
| Yii version      | 2.0.11
| PHP version      | 7.1.1
| DB version | PostgreSQL 9.5.2
| Operating system | Linux Mint 17.3 Cinnamon 64-bit
